definition: Product Requirements Document - A document that outlines the purpose, features, functionality, and behavior of a product or feature.
Application Programming Interface - A set of protocols and tools for building software applications that allow different systems to communicate.
Minimum Viable Product - A product with just enough features to satisfy early customers and provide feedback for future development.
Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment - Practices that enable teams to frequently deliver code changes through automated builds and deployments.
A sequence of tasks or steps that are executed in a specific order to achieve a particular outcome.
An autonomous software entity that performs tasks on behalf of users, often using AI to make decisions.
A user archetype that represents a specific type of user with distinct needs, goals, and behaviors.
The process of transferring control or information from one agent or user to another during a workflow.
A recorded choice or determination made during a workflow that affects the project's direction.
A saved state of the workflow at a specific point in time that can be restored if needed.
A fixed time period (usually 2 weeks) during which a specific set of work must be completed.
A short description of a feature from the perspective of the end user, typically following the format: As a [user], I want [goal] so that [benefit].
Representational State Transfer - An architectural style for designing networked applications using standard HTTP methods.
A library for ASP.NET that enables real-time, bidirectional communication between server and client.
Any person, group, or organization that has an interest in or is affected by the project.
A situation where two or more decisions or actions are incompatible and require resolution.
A collection of terms and their definitions specific to a particular domain or project.
A specific iteration or release of a document, code, or product.
